content.description:
Gain a vegetated ledge 2/3rds the way up, then fire off into some sweet face and arete moves. Super fun movement.  

  The crux is high on the arete. The line takes you on an adventure! 

  The lower part requires a bit of balance. 

  Equipped by Jeff Engel.
content.protection: GI bolts - very well protected, just don't blow it while wandering up the ledge to the top part of the climb
content.location: This route takes the dihedral on the right side of the booty wall.

content.description: Another line born from the Save Sandstone Festival. A burly undercling crux starts the route, followed by a crimper traverse and gaston sequences. Although relatively short, this techy climb packs a punch on some pretty cool sequences. If only it could continue for longer.
content.location: Located in between Adoption / Arbor Day and the arete.

content.description:
Getting off the ground is interesting. Rest of the route is moderate. Good fun warm up. Go WAY left to make it easy, or veer right to get full value.

 When we cleaned off the bottom part of the climb we found some graffiti on the wall. Go climb it and see what it says :)

 Equipped by Jeff Engel.

 Send it in the dark. If you're going to TR - follow / unclip as it wanders.
content.location: Furthest left line on relationship wall.

content.description: This short but stellar rig tackles the center of the "booty wall", equipped by Jeff Engel, Tyler Hoffart and their wonderful group of volunteers for the 2013 Save Sandstone Festival. Start on crimper sequences to the second bolt and move to the amazing, obvious arched slopper. Get tricky with your feet and figure out how not to peel off. The crux is short lived - easier yet engaging climbing will bring you to the chains.
content.location: If looking up at the Relationships Wall, this climb will appear about 50 yards to your right and starts in the center of "the pit". Currently it is the first bolted climb right of the bolted arete.

content.description: Second bolted route from the left on Relationship Wall. Slighlty loose flake to face and pockets above. Consistently fun moves throughout.
content.location: Relationship Wall. The first obvious face climb on the left side, usually well chalked.

content.description: Same start as Adoption but veer right near top.

I thought I'd add this in hopes more people do this very fun link up. It starts on compromises and traverses over to adoption after the 4th bolt. There is a bolt protecting the traverse. You get the hard parts of both routes with a little less pump than adoption and a little more cruxin' than compromises. 

 Also, the best warm up you have ever had is doing compromises, the linkup, and adoption in rapid succession. 

 Any knowledge of the actual name, FA or equipper would be appreciated.

(Equipped by J. Engel and M. Endrizzi) 15 feet right of "Compromises". This is an excellent route with the 2 cruxes: one at the very start and one at the very end. Crank up on small but good in-cuts to do a hand & foot match (yoga practitioners will find this easier than most). Climb vertical rail feature to a whitish, slightly mungy section about halfway up. Move left and then up through large horizontal cracks to upper headwall. Hopefully, you've saved a little juice to pull through the last move crux using the pods and slots that take you to the top.

Small crag with two walls separated by a 90-degree arête. The most popular west-facing wall, easily seen from the drive-in trail just past the picnic area, hosts high-quality Compromises and Adoption. The south-facing wall (with difficult Harvest Moon and dirty Start New ) is often damp and may take longer to dry out after extended period of rain.
